pull.title: Change "insane" to "excessive" (referring to high fees) in text strings and identifiers
pull.body:
This is clearer and more meaningful, as well as avoiding ableist langage (see http://www.autistichoya.com/p/ableist-words-and-terms-to-avoid.html ).

Note that this will also require translation changes in Transifex for the key
"A fee higher than %1 is considered an insanely high fee." which is now
"A fee higher than %1 is considered an excessive fee."

Signed-off-by: Daira Hopwood daira@jacaranda.org

events.message:
Change "insane" to "excessive" (referring to high fees) in text strings and identifiers.

Note that this will also require translation changes in Transifex for the key
"A fee higher than %1 is considered an insanely high fee." which is now
"A fee higher than %1 is considered an excessive fee."

Signed-off-by: Daira Hopwood <daira@jacaranda.org>

events.body: There are 10 languages on Transifex that have a translation for the changed key; I'm happy to change those translations if this pull request is accepted.

Excessive is misleading.  I would be glad if we changed to avoid any language that was derogatory towards anyone, but I think a different word would be better.  Paying $10 for a soft drink would be excessive especially if one was available down the street for $2,  paying $10,000 would be completely nonsensical. It's the latter the software is trying to prevent. (It doesn't prevent merely excessive)

Would nonsensical be acceptable?

Note also that there's a source-level backward incompatibility for anything compiled against Bitcoin Core that relies on `WalletModel::InsaneFee`. (There's no binary incompatibility since `WalletModel::ExcessiveFee` will take the same integer value.) If necessary I can add an `InsaneFee = ExcessiveFee` alias to avoid this.
Nonsensical or absurd would be fine. I vote for "absurd" (or "absurdly high"), in that case.

Absurd sounds great to me, but you might want to wait a bit to see if anyone else comments (I don't want to make you iterate on this if other people have opinions that differ greatly from mine).

I don't think we mind the incompatibility, though we are library structured, it's not a supported thing for external applications yet. (Oh, and I seemed to fail to say so explicitly the first response: thanks for taking a look, commenting, and making your comments concrete in the form of a patch. I'm always glad to have more perspectives; as soon as you pointed out the implication I realized I'd been careless in my word choice when I introduced the original language).

I didn't know of the word inordinate, so I suppose other non-native English speaking people can have problems with it.

So +1 for absurd.

How about "excessive"?

Absurd sounds a bit excessive a warning to me.

@MineForeman : @gmaxwell said that "excessive" was not the intended meaning, since the check doesn't prevent fees that are merely excessive. The consensus seems to be for "absurdly high" so I'll go with that.

I also checked the other languages on Transifex (there are more than 10 with a translation for this string; I had missed some):

French:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#fr/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
Des frais suprieurs  %1 sont considrs comme follement levs.
Fees higher than %1 are considered {wildly, foolishly} high.
Seems fine.

German:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#de/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
Eine hhere Gebhr als %1 wird als unsinnig hohe Gebhr angesehen.
A fee higher than %1 is considered an {absurdly, nonsensically} high fee.
This is fine.

Danish:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#da/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
Et gebyr hjere end %1 anses som et vanvittigt hjt gebyr.
A fee higher than %1 is considered as a {crazily, insanely} high fee.
Eek, this may need retranslation by a Danish speaker.
http://ordnet.dk/ddo/ordbog?query=vanvittig makes it clear that this word has undesired mental health connotations.

Dutch:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#nl/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
Transactiekosten hoger dan %1 worden gezien als waanzinnig hoog.
Transaction costs are higher than %1 are considered {outrageously, insanely, delusionally} high.
This probably also needs retranslation.
(see http://www.etymologiebank.nl/trefwoord/waanzinnig )

Spanish:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#es/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
Una comisin mayor de %1 se considera increblemente alta.
A fee higher than %1 is considered incredibly high.
Completely fine.

Catalan:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#ca/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#ca_ES/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
Una comissi superior a %1 es considera una comissi excessiva.
A fee higher than %1 is considered an excessive fee.
Might not have the intended meaning.

Italian:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#it/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
Una commissione pi alta dell'%1  considerata insensatamente alta.
A fee higher than %1 is considered {senselessly, irrationally, foolishly, unreasonably} high.
I think this is okay but it might be useful to ask a native speaker, since "insensato" can
also mean "stupid" when applied to people.

Norwegian Bokml:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#nb/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
Et gebyr hyere enn %1 er ansett som et sinnsykt hyt gebyr.
A fee higher than %1 is considered an insanely high fee.
Needs retranslation. The literal meaning of sinnsykt is "mentally sick".

Swedish:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#sv/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
En avgift hgre n %1 anses som en onormalt hg avgift.
A fee higher than %1 is considered as an abnormally high fee.
Seems fine.

Russian:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#ru/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
 ,  %1,   .
A fee more than %1 is considered {extremely, unbelieveably, incredibly} high.
Seems fine.

Ukrainian:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#uk/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
 ,  %1   .
A fee more than %1 is considered {wildly, incredibly} high.
Seems fine.

Turkish:
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#tr/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
%1 tutarndan yksek cret delicesine ar yksek bir cret olarak kabul edilir.
A fee higher than %1 is considered an insanely excessive cost.
Probably needs retranslation.

Chinese (China/simplified):
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#zh_CN/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
 %1  
Greater than %1 transaction fee will be deemed {excessive, exorbitant, too high} transaction fees.
 seems not to be ableist, but it might not have the intended meaning for the same reason "excessive" doesn't.

Chinese (Taiwan/traditional):
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#zh_TW/qt-translation-010x/37434907?q=insanely
 %1 
Greater than %1 transaction fee will be considered {abnormal, fraudulent, iniquitous}.
Hmm. Not sure that  (translated by Google as "abnormal", but  is translated as "fraud")
has the intended meaning either.

(also en_GB which should be the same as en)

Needs retranslation for ableist language: Danish, Dutch, Norwegian Bokml, probably Turkish, possibly Italian
Needs retranslation for meaning: Chinese (China and Taiwan), Catalan

issue.title: Change "insane" to "absurd" (referring to high fees) in text strings and identifiers
issue.body:
Note that this will also require translation changes in Transifex for the key
"A fee higher than %1 is considered an insanely high fee." which is now
"A fee higher than %1 is considered an absurdly high fee."
(see https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/5727#issuecomment-72341948 )

Signed-off-by: Daira Hopwood daira@jacaranda.org

events.body: Danish has been fixed ( https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/viewstrings/#da/qt-translation-011x/37434907?q=absurd ). I submitted the old, unproblematic translations for German, Russian, and Ukrainian.

issue.title: "Absurd" fee check leads to metadata leakage for small transaction amounts
issue.body:
### Describe the issue

The Zcash protocol supports amount=0 transactions and this is a very efficient way to utilize the memo field. But there is a "fee sanity" check in z_sendmany:
```
        // Check that the user specified fee is sane.
        if (nFee > nTotalOut) {
            throw JSONRPCError(RPC_INVALID_PARAMETER, strprintf("Fee %s is greater than the sum of outputs %s", FormatMoney(nFee), FormatMoney(nTotalOut)));
        }
```
which makes the default fee of 0.0001 invalid for any amount less than that fee. Some users are quick to figure out that if they change their network fee to 0, that *seems* to often work, depending on mempool conditions and network capacity.

This is bad for a number of reasons:
* It's bad from a UI perspective, because why is sending a transaction for amount=0 or any amount<fee different and weird?
* It's bad for miners, because users are encouraged to "work around a UI bug" by setting amount=0 to send their transaction, to utilize memo data. These transactions are pure overhead for miners, they get no transaction fees.
* It's bad from a user education perspective, because people learn "fee=0 transactions seem to work fine and are cheaper" while not understanding that it is *miners* who decide which fees to accept into a block, and fee=0 transactions very well could be dropped or expire in the future when the network is busier
* Finally, it's really bad for metadata leakage. One can search for fee=0 transactions and then one can then say that all amount=0 transactions are in that subset, because the code forces it to be that way. This would allow profiling certain users of Zcash protocol applications, i.e. HushList-enabled wallets. 


### Can you reliably reproduce the issue?

Yes, it's on latest git master in `src/wallet/rpcwallet.cpp`

#### If so, please list the steps to reproduce below:
1. Try to make a transaction for amount=0 and standard fee. It will fail.
2. Change fee=0.
3. The transaction proceeds (depending on chain and network capacity)

### Expected behaviour

The *default* fee should always be a valid fee amount, even for transactions less than the default fee.
This can be implemented simply by checking if the fee amount is different from the default fee, before 
the current "fee sanity check" code runs.

### Actual behaviour + errors

Current z_sendmany checks teach users to use fee=0 transactions if they want to do an amount=0 transaction, which is less than ideal.


### The version of Zcash you were using:

Latest zcash master

labels.name: I-privacy
labels.description: Problems and improvements related to privacy.
